smhjLbmxQzrgxA9xdKH9vw.review_text: The absolute best happy hour anywhere !  $5-7 appetizers and $5 wine  Wonderful, eclectic menu...great views and fun patrons... $10 parking a few doors down unless you're a local.....  The pig lettuce wraps are great as were the Kobe beef sliders.... and oooooooooooooh that calamari..... YUM !  The regular dinner menu is a tad steep so on occasion okay...but definitely make it to happy hour !

VrjXK3fRFB_xAdhyzOvOeg.review_text: went for my 5th year Anniversary and the food was so DELICIOUS!!! Great service too. Will return definitely.

CDQJgR5pT_StGorM82JogA.review_text: Had brunch last Saturday. Food was great! I had the poached egg with kalhua pig and my girlfriend had the poached egg with crab cakes. Both were excellent. Service was great. Our server was very attentive. The only thing I did not like was their coffee (never hot enough, even if was freshly poured). The Chef/owner even stopped by our table to say hello and see if we enjoyed the food.

qWOqPXPcaz_vz_ki2n1I8A.review_text: I have always wanted to try this place and my friend and I finally did last night. We celebrated a milestone in her life and the place was perfect for that. Big props to them for participating in Dining Out for Life (fighting AIDS) as well!   After a slow start with our waitress, things moved along quickly once we ordered our food.  They brought edamame that was nicely seasoned with salt and sesame seeds.   We ended up sharing a bunch of appetizers that was almost too much food--nice sized portions:  - kalua pork lettuce wraps (sooo good) - fried calamari (excellent) - ahi tuna roll - mussels and clams in thai coconut curry sauce   We shared the BANANA BREAD PUDDING WITH MITCHELL'S MACAPUNO ICE CREAM for dessert. Oh sooo good--even my friend liked it and she is quite the baker.  Nice view and nice space, not too loud. We had a sweet window seat where we could talk and watch a sea lion play around for a bit.

4BxI8ZBIpJiSbLhQfHtkng.review_text: This place is horrible.  Besides the wonderful location and the nice decor I would have to give a one star for food and service.  The price is unreasonable for what you are getting.  If you are just looking for a place to grab a drink and talk this would be nice but for a sit down resturant....I would look else where.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: It's nice to see a restaurant find its wings again as my last experience three years ago was a bit on the marginal side. But as Dolly Parton so wisely composed in her Tennessee backwoods youth... Love is like a butterfly As soft and gentle as a sigh The multicolored moods of love are like its satin wings Love makes your heart feel strange inside It flutters like soft wings in flight Ain't that purty...and gee, it has nothing to do with this restaurant, but I find you can always trust a large-breasted woman. 40 Double-D cup size just so y'know. And if the "girls" are wrong, who cares? They rule the world. And so does chef Robert Lam who has obviously sharpened the execution of his Asian fusion menu to a fine polish by now. Before, there was often a cloying sweetness to the dishes, but that wasn't evident this time around. No, the multicolored moods of our food were like the satin... well, you catch my drift. I came here with Jamie W. and a foodie friend who had suggested we take advantage of the Dine Around Town promotion. My prior experiences with DAT menus have been hit-and-miss since restaurants often don't showcase their best dishes for the discounted prices, but Lam and crew pulled all the stops with a superb execution of their three-course $36.95 dinner special plus a few other items we couldn't resist. First up were the fusion-forward appetizers. The Salt and Pepper Fried Calamari had welcome touches of sweet (Ponzu-marinated cucumbers) and spice (Tabasco remoulade) (photo: bit.ly/1mkCoO1). The Duck Confit Spring Rolls were concurrently moist and crunchy with the obligatory Chinese mustard and honey sauce providing the optimal balance of hot and sweet (photo: bit.ly/1o93RXc). The best of the trio was the Kahlua Pig in Butter Lettuce Cups accompanied by a hoisin BBQ sauce, pepper brunoise, toasted cashews and scallions (photo: bit.ly/1jTWS08). As if that wasn't enough for pre-entree gluttony, we also ensnared and shared two Happy Hour specials: the Sesame-Coated Edamame sprinkled with Hawaiian Red Sea Salt (photo: bit.ly/1iMww53) and four spoonfuls of  Bacon Dates with Maytag blue cheese, cashews and Pat Chun vinegar (photo: bit.ly/1o944cT). Both provided more than satisfying mouthfuls which tied us over to our main courses. Two of us (including me) were in a risk-averse mode and ordered the Teriyaki Grilled Hanger Steak medium rare. While you might expect a predictably oversweetened rendition from past experience, it was instead tempered expertly with a potato leek gratin, sugar snap and sweet pea stir fry, sliced portobello mushrooms, and a miso jus de veau (photo: bit.ly/1nKVL5q). The result was savory splendor without being the least bit cloying. Jamie surprised me by requesting the Young Turmeric Grilled Snapper, a hearty filet with caramelized onions and herbs, rice noodles, butter lettuce cups and a nuoc cham dipping sauce (photo: bit.ly/TDAv8H). It was a veritable feast fit for Neptune, at least if Neptune turned out to be a pescetarian with a pitchfork. Room for dessert? Oh sure, why not go all the way. We all ordered the Warm Banana Bread Pudding with Macapuno Ice Cream (photo: bit.ly/1iMx3E4). It worked because it was comparatively petite and packed with island-style flavor. By the way, I couldn't possibly neglect mention of the stellar cocktails. I first had a Dirty Ketel One martini at their $8 Happy Hour price (photo: bit.ly/1wEDjRi), and then upon recognition of an unexpected lull in the service, we were rewarded with complimentary Espresso Martinis, which weren't even on their bar menu but executed with style and precision nonetheless by the bartender (photo: bit.ly/UPhIbd). The setting is as cavernous as my last visit, but it looks like they dismantled the window booths for more open views. Smart move. Jamie mentioned they should consider moving the bar to the street side so passers-by could see what a convivial place it is.Good suggestion.  Even as we were rendered immobile from our shared gluttony, chef Lam took the initiative to be warm and cordial to us (photo: bit.ly/1vcP6DU). When Jamie mentioned to him that I Yelped, he immediately recognized me as Ed U. and complimented my by calling me his Food Buddha - even though I was probably rubbing my ample belly at the time. I think I turned beet red. FOOD - 5 stars...a major upgrade from my previous experience here...now truly a culinary destination worth mentioning to fellow foodies AMBIANCE - 4 stars...still cavernous, still a tad noisy but not too crowded SERVICE - 5 stars...thanks to chef Lam's personal attention, a major plus TOTAL - 5 stars...this Food Buddha is happy to rediscover the satin wings of this Butterfly

7bAnU8PIEmAV_tUeaIdCaw.review_text: Good view of the bay, nice and spacious ambiance. Friendly service, the chef came out to greet us at the end of the meal. I came here for lunch and I had the grilled ahi tuna, it was good but the dishes are way too overpriced especially for Vietnamese fusion. A good place to bring out of town guests.

uVFi5sTagsvFz-8tw0L_7g.review_text: Friendly hostess, beautiful view, good fusion food.  Were seated next to the window!  Complimentary edamame had way too much sesame oil.  The special was soft shell crab sandwich served with fries.  Fries were perfectly cooked, soft on the inside and crispy outside.  Also had the red snapper, portion was decent.  Served with 4 pieces of butter lettuce which had holes in 2 pieces :( also came with vermicelli rice noodles and carrot/daikon in vinegar.  Instead of making lettuce wrap, had to eat with a fork because of the 'holey' lettuce.  Still delicious though.  Service was not the most attentive.

7myt5OtQNWcE1INmEFO5kA.review_text: Alright so this is a review of the place as a nightclub and first 1 star rating here on yelp so a business seriously needs to screw up for me to get such a low rating. Came here for their Halloween thing since friend had some friends coming. First off paid $20 for a ticket which wasn't bad for a Halloween party and girls would be free before 10 with a costume. As always the line moved slowly like any nightclub and the girls had to pay $40 each to get in. What a rip off!! Got inside with my friends and I could count exactly 2 Halloween decorations in the place. For $40 you would think they could do a better job but I guess not. Definitely not coming back to this place for any of their night time affairs and there's no in-n-outs so what's the point of the stamp??

LMNXDf-LsqEnwdprxv3OEg.review_text: We had a great dinner here last week.  We didn't get a window seat but we could still see the bay from our table. To start, I had a lemonade while my partner had a lychee cocktail, both of which were very good. For an appetizer, I had the duck confit sping rolls while my partner had the Kalua pig with butter lettuce cups.  My spring rolls were piping hot so I had to wait a bit to enjoy them.  Once I did, I enjoyed them with the honey-mustard dipping sauce.  A word of warning: the dipping sauce has wasabi which is quite hot.  I tasted the Kalua pig wrapped in lettuce and it was absolutely delicious. For entrees, I had the sesame-crusted ahi tuna which was perfectly prepared and delicious.  My partner had the curry-spiced diver scallops which were perfectly prepared and served on top of a very nice risotto. I was too full for dessert but tried my partner's banana bread pudding with ice cream and bananas brulee and it was delicious. The service was excellent.  Interestingly, we had four different servers, all of whom were very good and handsome in their black shirts, black slacks and black dress shoes. I recommend Butterfly very highly and would return again.

2gw3JlPBq2Q6owtmNcE0Rw.review_text: The ambiance here is very cool.  Food presentation was excellent.  Cocktails were delicious.

0oE1TAVdqH7-9Z7DXKy0jA.review_text: This place has the best ambiance and it's right on the water! I love coming here! The food is also very tasty and amazing! I felt like I scored when I found a Groupon for this place.

SLvoPK9cnGvEQIJY-TIdWw.review_text: We went to Butterfly for our anniversary dinner, and it was awesome.  The hostess sat us at a two-person table, with both of us facing the water.  The server's (Mariah) recommendations for food and wine pairings were spot on, the presentation was awesome, and the price was really reasonable for what we got.  We had the shrimp/green papaya salad, seared ahi and Peking duck - all delicious.  Definitely recommend!

ipleTHGh9KR8hO5U1yxzXw.review_text: I hadn't seen him in over a year but owner/chef Rob Lam greeted me at the door and remembered me immediately.   The Kobe Burger is definitely the highlight of the lunch menu.  It was flavorful and exactly what I was craving for lunch. We were even given a creme brulee to share! Nothing says "Yay it's Friday" like burnt sugar and custardy goodness at the end of lunch.  The waitress was slow to get our sodas and check but we were in and out in just under and hour so maybe I'm just impatient (which everyone knows I am.) I don't think that a weekday lunch should take an hour though...

Rjd9Td7yYOqu0A1e2KDAyA.review_text: Went to this place because my wife's friend's brother owns it.  It's a fusion restaurant on the pier, so the view is nice. The food is overpriced, but it's expected based on the location.   The pig in a hole was pretty good, lettuce cups were alright, garlic noodles were better than average and the salmon/strawberry rolls were interesting.  I'm a little harsher on expensive places because if I pay more, I expect more.   My wife found a couple of pet hairs in her lettuce. She asked to have it done again and although she was apologized to and got a new one, you would think a manager would address it or at least give us a discount. It's the little things that add or subtract a star.   Seems like the place does pretty good business and on Sundays the bottomless mimosas keep people there for a while.   The place was alright, but not my keep of tea.

u6ms8jCUMd3qhlB6hufV-w.review_text: We recently came to Butterfly for a cocktail party, and had a wonderful time! The space was very sleek and chic, with enourmous windows spotlighting the amazing views of the East Bay. It was really hot in the venue, perhaps due to a suprise Indian Summer night, so we spent a lot of time out on the narrow patio enjoying the spectacular view. Inside, we hit the busy dancefloor, and on the edges of the room it was tough to carry on any coversation.   The primary bar was packed, and we waited about 10 minutes at a time for drinks. Service was very slow, but the lycheetini was fantastic, and the vodka tonics were nice and strong! At one point I got a gin and tonic by mistake. Normally I'd ask for another drink, but I couldn't stand waiting in line again.The second bar, with much shorter lines, was hard to spot and only took cash.

Agf6L4QPq9oCKTaz7odUkw.review_text: 01/25/2015 Trying out their $40 Dine About Town menu. As I walked in to the restaurant, I was greeted by the hostess. Generally your first impression starts with the hostess. Her social skills must have come from being trained in a Chinatown restaurant. This just means I need to drink more. The windows span from the floor to the ceiling with unobstructed view of the Bay and giant sea urchans hanging from the ceiling. So they are not presenting their Dine About Town menu with their regular menu. You actually have to ask for it (well I did, saw a couple across the table with DAT menu in main menu) Thought this was for charity.   So I ordered the Duck Confit, Hanger Steak, and Banana Bread Pudding and for a drink I ordered the Honey Bourbon. They didn't put a napkin down on the table for the drinks. Now they are sliding around on the lacquered table.   The complimentary pre-course was Sesame Seed Oiled Edamame, a Oyster Amuse Bouche, which tastes like a Spicy Bloody Mary, Shiso Leaf Poke and Spam Onigira (fried spam roll). This was very yummy and a great way to start the taste buds.   The Duck Confit with the Mustard Sauce was good. Not great. It's a cut up egg roll with sauce. What more can you do with it.   The Hanger Steak was good. A perfect medium rare. And the Demi glaze was perfect with the potatoes. I'd order this again    Now I'm fat and here comes dessert. Banana Bread Pudding. This was so delicious, warm, and cool with the ice cream and caramel.   Total bill came out to just over $50. Well worth the try. If you can, eat there for lunch and enjoy the view of the bay.

qPCUIYg0GzZAXPTGAr8iRA.review_text: Great place and good service.  I wanted to find a resto with a view and came across Butterfly which also was listed under Dine about town! Jack pot.  Coz earlier I had looked up Slanted Door and was quite disappointed that for a group of 6 or more they only offer fixed price per person which way too expensive for lunch! So I called here and reserved table with view.  Our group got the secluded table and absolutely loved the decor! All three appetizers and entree from the DAT menu was ordered! Also I tried the Virgin Lycheetini which was very sweet.  They serve huge portion except for the Smoked Salmon entree.  The texas toast was too heavy.    All in all great place and is good for special occasions.  Since its at Pier 33, its very close to Pier 39 and walk little more to get to Fisherman's wharf.  Parking is convenient if you park between Bay St and Embarcadero.

8Z9ugoA4MGwiJVh-CB8bhQ.review_text: The Fi and I decided to do DAT for lunch and decided upon Butterfly amongst others also participating Sunday lunches. Upon entering I immediately wished we were 10 seconds quicker b/c the couple who entered right before us got the last available window seats (dammit!). I tried to stick to the DAT menu however the 2nd course didn't include any vegetarian friendly dishes so I had to order from the main menu. Between the Fi and I we had the sesame seed edamame (complimentary appetizers) ceasar salad, fired fried calamari, chicken club sandwiches with fries, garlic noodles and for dessert we shared the creme brulee. I also ordered a VIRGIN mojito. We enjoyed all our dishes and especially loved the creme brulee which was very simple but tasty.  Next time we're going to try for the window seating.

_rEHCgvV0CbcbdZkIyZVyg.review_text: Walked in today a little after 5pm with my husband and asked for a table next to the window with a water view. The hostess asked us if we have a reservation and we told her no. She stuck us in this corner table where I have little view of water. When we left at 6pm, there were only two people at the bar and two other people in the whole restaurant!  A couple with two young children walking in and got seated at a window seat right away. Food was ok and waiter was nice enough. I just cannot believe the hostess who sat us at a corner with no water view when the whole restaurant was pretty much empty. I will never return to this place with a hostess who treats her customers so poorly.

-dUpR3WlVK016ZXqETXMMg.review_text: Heard about this place through Dine About Town.  We had their Pre-Fixe menu for $17 per person. Comes with your own appetizer & entree. My cousin and I got the infamous calamari & pork lettuce wraps. Thanks to my fellow yelpers it was Amazing!! The calamari was nice and crunchy and the pulled pork lettuce wraps was soo good! As our entree I ordered the shaking beef salad. I didn't feel the egg on top so I just put it on the side. Our server Kristine was very nice! I wanted a sangria with red wine but I didn't see it on the menu.. she was nice enough to make it anyway and it was soo delish! Will come back here once they have this event again!

wCtf5_zG8EpWiBp_Oi7P0g.review_text: This place looks cooler on the inside and outside than it actually is. I've only been here for late night events when we have rented it out but the bar tenders had trouble making drinks with actual alcohol in them--in other words they were kinda weak which usually doesn't happen in SF!! The views from this place is what earns it its three stars and it is right on the embarcadero so pretty good placement for other restaurants and lounges and getting a cab later on in the night--but for me weak drinks kinda kill anyone's experience

-shHTy1CEmSMPVSehdASaw.review_text: Located on the Embarcadero, Butterfly is an Asian fusion restaurant which seems to be more Western with Asian influences than the other way around.   We went for dinner recently during the Christmas holidays.  There's plentiful and expensive ($15) parking in a private lot across the street.  It's very trendy inside, but it's pretty dark and actually a bit hard to see.  The restaurant features a large window facing the Bay, but it's really dark out there if there aren't any boats, so we really didn't see much.  Plus the reflection of the large Christmas wreaths from across the room didn't help.    Service was excellent.  We had a veggie appetizer which was forgettable, but the fried calamari was good.  The cream based mushroom soup featured a foamy steamed milk top and was very tasty.  The kaluha pig and hoisin sauce on lettuce cups was an interesting combo and very good.  The pig is very filling all by itself due to its richness.    I had the hanger steak and it was cooked perfectly.  The rice discs and carrots and greens were very tasty.  But the sauce was overpowrering.  And too salty for my taste.  Otherwise, it was a good dish.  Others in my party had the cod, the snapper, and the gnocchi.  They voiced their approval.    We had the lychee ice for dessert.  Very tasty.  This could be a four star place.  I'll have to try it again.  We used a Living Social certificate that saved us $25.  The only negative here is that according to their website, they have an early bird fixed price special during the week.  They didn't tell us about it when we were given menus and I had to ask to get the special menu.  Why?

alEd1mZ_l-DVtS3Ar5bMLA.review_text: This is definitely what I envision when a restaurant claims to be Asian Fusion, an actual integrative taste.  Usually when I go to Asian Fusion restaurants, it tastes like Americanized Asian food.  Today, I ordered the Pig in a hole sandwich, which is served on thick, buttery bread. A hole is cut in the center and an egg is in its place.  The sandwich includes kalua pork, bacon, and cheese.  The sandwich was served with fruit, lettuce, onions, pickles, and steak fries.  My friend ordered the mushroom scramble.  We started off the meal with a ceasar salad (one order split in two=plenty).  Everyone gets edamame which seems to be seasoned with sesame oil and seeds.  The sandwich melted in your mouth.  My only suggestion for improvement is possibly serving the sandwich on thinner bread.  The crust was particularly hard to chew and I ended cutting it off.  I'm not a carb counter...I will eat them for sure, but there were so many carbs (fries and bread) that it just seemed to 'waste space' when the clear winner was the middle of the sandwich.    A bonus is the waiter was very attentive.  We were engrossed in deep conversation, and so we didn't necessarily need all the attention, but it was nice to see that he cared.  A great experience especially if you are in the area.  Today King Street was closed off for the street fair so it was a bit of a challenge to drive here and park.  It was worth it though!  It was nice to see the club/lounge that I liked to go to a few years back is actually a great restaurant too!

XrzkP-EPpql8cis-GlQ57A.review_text: Living in SF is wonderful. You have to admit though that each neighborhood is so self-sufficient that you could really get into a little routine of your own--always frequenting the same places such as: the bank that you can walk to, the coffee shop, the corner grocery stores, the neighborhood bars and restaurants etc.  And. then you have that (eureka!) moment one day when you realize and/or remember that there are other parts of the city to explore!   This is why I am recommending that you try Butterfly.  It's a restaurant on Bay Street/Embarcadero that sits on the water.  It's a reminder as to why SF is known for it's restaurants.  The decor is really cool with those huge hanging  sea urchin- like lamps and interesting lighting throughout.  The portions are generous!  We started with:   Kalua Pig with Butter Lettuce Cups 10 Hoisin Barbeque Dipping Sauce, Pepper Brunoise, Toasted Cashews, Minced Green Onions AND Garlic Seared Clams & Mussels 12 Lemongrass and Coconut Curry Broth, Sesame Grilled Bread, Picked Cilantro Leaves  We then shared the  Classic Caesar Salad 10 Chilled Hearts of Romaine, Parmesan Croutons, Fresh Grated Parmesan Cheese  Next came the entrees.  We both had the same dish: Crab & Mascarpone Stuffed Crispy Chicken Breast 25 Sweet Summer Corn and Rock Shrimp Ragout, Arugula Salad Aged Balsamic Vinegar, Lobster and Orange Reduction  Again people---the portions are GENEROUS. (sorry about the caps but I wanted to emphasize the portion size!)  Dessert was: Banana Bread Pudding 7  We each had 2 martinis--I tried the lycheetini (Belvedere vodka, lychee puree)--and a glass each of Noah's Zinfandel.  The martini was tasty but too sweet for me so I switched back to just Belvedere with 2 olives. The zinfandel was a great find!  And, it was 8 bucks a glass.  The entire bill came to $154.00 and we went home with a doggy bag.  I only gave this restaurant 3 stars because the service was a bit lacking.  Here's why in no particular order:   (forgotten bread plates, forgotten tableware, no bread and water until they "remembered" to bring it out, soiled napkins (from eating that delicious Kalua Pig wrap) weren't replaced until asked, the waiter  kept hitting my chair with his foot, they never lit the candle on our table, the wine took forever to get to the table, we were never "crumbed", a waitress dropped a huge wine glass in front of our table and it hit the floor so hard that it shattered by at least 4 tables and took a while to clean up)  Yes, I'm going back--the food is tasty and creative.  The chef took his time and visited every table to see how the food was--and, it felt great to get out of the neighborhood that we live in.

y842YtSmu9Z43NhHyrAVlA.review_text: Uh-mazing!  Overall:4.5 stars, with a 5 star round up!  Service: Fantastic Food: Delectable  Drinks: Adequate Location: Convenient with a view  Ambiance: Romantic    We made a reservation for 7:30pm for the "dine about SF/SF Restaurant Week" selection priced at $40.00 per person. The pricing was definitely reasonable for the portion of the food and the quality of the other characteristics. Amuse: simply intoxicating, both of us were trying to pick one and we found out you wet given all three each! There was a Bloody Mary oyster shooter, a poke bite, and a spam fried concoction (which took us both by surprise in how decadent it tasted). Order wise I would say go: 1. Poke  2. Bloody Mary oyster shooter (fabulous)  3. The spam bite ...but that's just me. All three were great, the poke had a bit too much of leaf flavor (personally) but my friend loved every bite. Regarding number one I would suggest putting it in your chomper at one time but try to roll it around in your mouth so you capture all of the flavor.  The appetizers we chose were the duck confit and pork lettuce wraps. Both. Were. Magnificent! We didn't choose the calamari because you could get that anywhere but I'm sure it would be amazing as well! Personally, I liked the pork better...there were so many flavors in one but the duck was definitely scrumptious as well. Every last bite was gone and the sauce the duck came with was mui delicioso! Haha. For the main course I had the catfish and my friend had the animal style (pork, steak, shrimp, and veggies) garlic noodles. Both were definitely big enough to share, we each ended up taking some home. The catfish was fresh and cooked to perfection, the steak in the garlic noodles was a bit over cooked for my personal taste but it has a great Korean-BBQ-flavor-ish. The pork was the best additive according to my friend and the garlic noodles melted in your mouth.  For dessert I got the creme brûlée and he got the banana bread pudding. He said there was some sort of "different taste" in there but he ate most of it and it looked divine. My creme brûlée was my first and it was great, I just have nothing to compare it to.  The drinks were standard and fair priced, their spiced apple cider was delicious! Plus, their tea was perfect for my little cold (non-alcoholic tea). Great experience, especially meeting one of the owners during our dessert course and we had a great server as well. All in all, we will be back again (especially in the day time to see the view since you're literally ON the water!)!! (The .5 deduction was for our server over charging us, brown lettuce (for the lettuce wraps) and forgetting a drink, he definitely made up for it with the bill, to go food, and the fact that he kept a smile on his face. Due to this it does not deter me in any way!)

2l4heqFZRNa6Rd7Wloh2Hw.review_text: Takeout Window Philosophy:  Take something bad that people really, really like and cram as much of it into their face as possible.   Tis the season so let's look on the bright side: You can completely rid your life of gluttonous indulgences because flashbacks of your takeout experience will trigger gag reflexes for at least a year.  *Their "shaking beef salad" freed me from cow and pig for about a month.*   *Their chicken salad sandwich cured me from mayonnaise for, well, forever.*

db5IRfVjD4vb7gNHrjxFLw.review_text: While waiting for our Alcatraz Tour Boat we found this place while looking for lunch.  Our lucky day!  My wife had the Acai Berry Lemonade and the Shrimp Salad and I had a coffee and the Chicken Club.  We split a Bread Pudding for dessert.  Everything was great tasting and with ample portions.  The Bread Pudding was awesome!  Service was very professional - polished and attentive.  Somewhat pricey, but you better expect it in that neighborhood.  Almost forgot, the great view of the harbor was an added bonus.  Would return again, maybe for dinner next time.

Czi7GtQdcfz2d7819K9y4g.review_text: Classy Dining in Fisherman's Wharf. What's not to enhjoy?

P00kV6mYF2mOtKQrJxeTlg.review_text: I really like this restaurant--it's always been on of my faves! =) Their ever-changing menu keeps things interesting! Once, I had a Vietnamese spring roll with salmon and strawberries in it! And, another time I ordered a Sangria, but it was see-through instead of red wine! Very innovative. I like their casual environment with a full bar, lounge area with a flat screen (always playing sports). Great place to take a date--one time, I was there with a gf and a huge group of people came in with #'s....speed dating! haha They also host club events during the weekends and they usually have some type of entertainment throughout the week--sometimes a violinist, dj, pianist, etc...

5GZmczpCuGkWJQrIjs5qAg.review_text: Worst celebration here ever. I do not recommend this place or its management.

K7xZtVLB7IwJOCE7IXWecw.review_text: Food was great. Service was ok.  I think the challenge was that our server was dealing with a huge party right before we got to our table. Would I go again? For the food yes for the service... it left a little more to be desired.

07zMwJGw3jJli33EzaJ6aQ.review_text: I had medium hopes for a fancy pants spot for my first stop of Dine About Town 2009 although I wasn't disappointed, I can't say calling moms about this place.  Once I learned it was an Asian fusion place, I was already a little wary. But, I'm always up for new foods and being objective about it. My appetizer was actually super tasty - smoked salmon carpaccio over wasabi crackers. But it is carpaccio if its smoked? These little tidbits didn't matter to me as it was so super tasty I nearly scarfed it down. The duck confit spring rolls were rather odd - a fried spectacle of of 4 powder covered rolls and some sweet sauce. The first thing that happens when I put it in my mouth is a sense of confusion as it was an extremely unexpected flavor that didn't really consist of much duck.   My main course was a hangar steak with mushrooms and potatoes au gratin - a little cold, a lot boring. The steak was rather tender, but the mushrooms were tastier than the steak. And the au gratin in a separate bowl was a mash of grease and government cheese. It was the most unspectacular boxed potatoes I'd had in a long time.  Dessert wasn't so horrible, but strangely described as a warm chocolate torte with coffee ice cream and rasberries. It shipped out to me with a single rasberry on top of a rather bland torte.   The service here was wonderful, but I typically like to think I've come to a restaurant for the food. I'm plenty used to cheap chinese restaurants with horrible service and excellent food. I'd just imagined that a pricier asian restaurant would have excellent food and excellent service. I just one one of the above.

aabGCUWIGHG6mNf8OpBfgg.review_text: Excellent spot for Sunday Brunch Best calamari ever Killer bottomless bloody marys The only thing tastier than my poached eggs on crab cakes was my wife's fried snapper sandwich

Js6UuHJtzw_9UQwPO_c-xA.review_text: I've been going to Butterfly for a few years now, and I can tell you that apart from the great location and fabulous views (which is why you will run into a few tourists occasionally), that this is an amazing little gem in the city. It's beautiful and it has amazing views with giant picture windows.   Apart from that, the food is incredible, and - most importantly - it's consistently good. The drinks are always great, and they have a happy hour cocktail that rotates out (always interesting). However, my favorites are the gin gimlet and the lycheetini [sp]. In terms of food, I highly recommend the fried squash (fresh buratta - so amazing!), and the duck confit rolls, as well as the garlic noodles.   But it's not just about the views and the food. The service is beyond compare. I have never been there when I haven't been treated well. One server in particular deserves mention - Porter. He was especially accommodating and lovely, and so funny & sweet. I think that, if I hadn't been there before, I would come back just for him! :)

scf89Snhi3knn4DO-KA2BQ.review_text: I found a new place to unwind and eat great food. The cheif was really awesome! My fav place in SF. Yummy..........love the food and the ambiance was great and the view of some part of the bay. Great for gathering and spending time with friends and family while having a great food.

WBaMDqyxGoKtqeVyh4SmHQ.review_text: Stopped in for Happy Hour while walking along the water.  Was a nice place, the bartender was great. Sat at the bar, not too busy considering it was around 6pm on a Friday.

kQculJdmDyBRG4WHKo6g7A.review_text: I'm only reviewing base on Happy Hour. The two star goes to the drink & decor of the place. The service was good mainly because it was slow. Food: I had calmari, clam & mussel, and a caesar salad. ONLY LIKED THE SALAD because it was the only thing that didn't taste salty. Drink: Kiwi martini. Good amount of alcohol. I kinda slurred after  I finished.

2jUEo2JNvxGUHVE22BaIqg.review_text: If you want a stylish place to bring a first date or out of town guests, Butterfly never fails to impress.  It's on the border between the stylish restaurants on the Embarcadero (nearer the Financial District) and the cheesy places of Fisherman's Wharf but Butterfly is definitely a good pick.  The interior is beautiful and looks out over the water.  The service is very polished but not stuffy.  The executive chef/owner is there most nights and he looks over every plate before it goes out (always a sign of a good place).  The real highlight of Butterfly is the food.  For appetizers, the Kailua Pig and the spring rolls never dissappoint.  Our party had the Salmon, Duck, Gnocchi and Roasted Chicken and all were outstanding!  Their happy hour specials at the bar are a bargain too.  The only reason they lost a star is that the prices are starting to get a bit high ($25-28 for each entree).  Still a winner for that special dinner

QDKZE64Ag94LbJcf0MlwCg.review_text: Great meal and great ambiance.  However what keeps us coming back over and over again is Porter.  He is very knowledgeable about the wine and menu is very friendly though not intrusive.  Last night we had the clams and mussels in a curry sauce that was really yummy though would have been better with bread.  I had the garlic noodles with shrimp and nearly ate the whole thing even though it was a huge portion and my partner had the stuffed chicken breast -  which he really enjoyed though thought it was a little too rich.  4 stars to butterfly and 5 stars to Porter.

AjHFgLursLNKyzsqG_Y4VA.review_text: I've been here a few times and have generally liked most what I've had. The most recent time I was here was early this year, to a restaurant that was not particularly busy. I ordered the vegetarian trio, which at the time consisted of a curry, fried onigiri, and a chawanmushi dish. The curry was possibly the best hearty curry of sweet potato and more, really good stuff. I also enjoyed the fried onigiri; it came with two crispy golden triangles. The egg dish was the one letdown, looking over-steamed and maybe too vinegary among other things. We mentioned this to the waiter since he asked how was the food, and the chef came out to check up on us. He admitted that the dish didn't look right, apologized, and mentioned and that he was trying to experiment with something new and still making tweaks for that 3rd item in the trio (normally a simple dish like pea shoots). Since we weren't happy, and learning that I was a "meat eater pretending to be vegetarian", he comped us an order of perfectly plated Shanghai garlic noodles with surf 'n turf(!), so that was pretty awesome. The shrimp and beef themselves were tender and a flavorful add-on to the bowl of noodles and veggies. This dish was good, although you need to know what you're getting into before you order it. They are not the heavily garlicky buttery noodles you can find in a lot of Vietnamese places around here. This has a lot more going on ingredient-wise, has more of an oyster sauce flavor, and the garlic is more subtle compared to the in-your-face punch of the vietnamese places.  I love that the chef takes pride in his cooking and is willing to push his boundaries, while being very considerate of his customers' feedback. The service here is good, ambiance a little on the classier side (which coincidentally makes their website theming look a bit out of place), and the drinks pretty tasty. Hope they keep on improving!

1kxrlI-ohR05UpSeUTRTBA.review_text: Went here for dinner with my girlfriend. Great atmosphere and the food was superb! Definitely a great place to take a date.  Appetizers: Duck Confit Spring Rolls and Caesar Salad Entrees: Pork Porterhouse and Bleu Cheese Macadamia Filet Mignon  Everything was very, very good. Waiters were extremely helpful and well-informed about the menu items! Will go again.

6q3RKPxoCV8ZxSFkILg1eg.review_text: I have to start off by saying for as much as this restaurant charges for it's tiny portions, the service was unbelievably slow and inattentive.  I was invited last night to attend my good friends pre-wedding dinner along with seven others. They knew well in advance we had a reservation for a larger party and you would think they would have their staff be more attentive, considering we would spending a lot of money, including having to pay an 18% automatic gratuity.  My husband and I arrived first and were seated. We ended up waiting over half an hour for the rest of our party to show up. In the meantime, it took the staff 20 of those minutes to offer us something to drink. Once the rest of the party came, it took another 30 minutes to ask them what THEY wanted to drink as well as take our orders.   In my opinion, the menu didn't offer much selection and everything seemed to run pretty expensive. We were already strapped for money prior to accepting the invitation to dinner, but felt even worst when there didn't seem to be anything worth the money to order. The others didn't seem overly impressed with the selection either, for that matter.  The hubby and decided to make a meal of appetizers; we ordered one of the fried calamari to split and two orders of the shanghai garlic noodles as our courses. Our first appetizer took over half an hour to arrive and our appetizer courses took another. I will say that although most of the food would be below average in flavor and size, the calamari was very good and the garlic noodles were a decent portion and had plenty of nicely grilled veggies and slices of roasted garlic in them.   Aside from our appetizers and the atmosphere, the service for the price you were paying was HIGHLY lacking and the 18% gratuity was more than what I would have paid for the kind of treatment the bride to be and the rest of us were getting.   Let me elaborate..They made no special attempt to see that our friend was having a good time right before her wedding, which you would think they would if they wanted us to recommend this place to others. I mean at least offer the bride a complimentary drink, dessert or appetizer for being so inattentive. Mind you it was not even crowded at that time and we waited an hour an half total for food and drinks, with only half an hour to enjoy them before having to leave.   I very rarely give two stars but I felt that waiting over an hour for someone to take our order and half another to get our drinks would justify this. The two stars I am giving is strictly for the location and our appetizers. I will also mention that it took them another half an hour to get our bill as my husband and I had to leave early because we had a long drive back to Vallejo and it was already 10pm. Our reservation was for 7:30 and most of that time was just spent on waiting for someone to acknowledge our presence. On another not so positive note, I noticed that the hostess wished everyone else a good night as they were leaving, however, didn't say a word to us.   Overall, I don't recommend coming here if you're starving, broke or just a tourist who has no idea that the city has plenty of other good dining districts. But if you just want to try some decent appetizers, I would tell you to use their "take our" window to avoid the long wait and having to pay a tip. Otherwise, if you truly want some really good fancy Asian fusion, I would recommend trying "The House" in the north beach district. The service there is average but the food will not disappoint and their dessert is just as creative and unique!

IqlXJuDDmx-y53oK-U5XjA.review_text: Location is good and food is fine. But they cheated on customers. The waitress gave me a coupon when I was reading their menu outside their restaurant that said I could get a free desert if I had two lunch orders. My wife and I then walked in and had a fine lunch but the free desert never came even after we asked our waitress three times.

qkreXL6AorI19QA3f2wvlQ.review_text: I had the duck over crepes and it was absolutely delicious. And the dessert was tasty too. The one thing that was lacking was my lycheetini. Maybe I was spoiled from the one I had in Hawaii, but it didn't look nor taste well.

STtTrCHMa_kHzxSkeqnFRA.review_text: Stopped in here waiting for our trip to Alcatraz since it is right next to it.  Great food and great service.  We sat at the bar and the bartender girl was awesome.  She had great recommendations on food and wine.  She made an awesome mojito or sumojito which is their specialty mojito.  The calamari was awesome.  We order it wherever my wife and I go, it is the best we have had (I estimate we have had calamari at about 60 different places).  The calamari is a must.  We also got the clam chowder duo, which was the red and the white.  They were both great.  The white was made to order and unique to the area.  A chunky type of white chowder and the red was really full of seafood.  My wife ordered a glass of wine and was treated to a mini wine tasting to find the one she wanted.  Everything was great.  We came here at lunch time, so that may have something to do with the great service and attention to detail with our food.  I will be back for the calamari if nothing else.

ItuJ3KfxtoPUVW1XNtk-9A.review_text: Service is standard but food is outstanding. Seafood stands out here. The edamame they give you in the beginning is amazing.  They do have special prix fixe menus and happy hour. It's all on their website. Check it out.

7PW4itmEgauvbHAZbbA8Jg.review_text: I was part of a group of 16 that visited Butterfly today.  And I told the server that I needed my order to be on a separate bill.  And he said, "I have to see".  It's like..what the heck?  Why can't you just put my order on a separate bill?    My fiance ordered the Kobe Beef Burger ($14) and I ordered the Red Snapper Sandwich ($11).  My fiance loved the burger and I think my red snapper sandwich could've been a lot better if it had some sort of spice, like jalepeno, on it.  Anyway, the service was not that great at all.  Some people ordered drinks and one of the group members didn't get his lemonade.  So, he told the waiter that he ordered the lemonade and didn't get it but would like to get a coke instead.  The guy didn't even say sorry.  On top of that, it took him another 10 minutes plus to bring a coke.  It wasn't even that busy!  It was freaking 2:30 p.m!  And I guess because the waiter already knew he was going to get 18% gratuity, he could've cared less.  And when the check came, of course, my order was on the same bill as others and I asked my portion to be separated from the rest.  And the stupid server already put 18% gratuity on my bill.  Look jerko...you didn't deserve no 18% gratuity!    Summary: food was good...service was sucky.

kesgqammgoKpBoykI1coCw.review_text: Absolutely 5 star for me. The chef has his own understanding of food. Like every dish~

zvNWyE9AL2AdE6G-LF9FQA.review_text: HAPPY HOUR REVIEW ONLY:  Went here for a birthday celebration and because we read on Yelp the Happy Hour was great. We had a great booth facing the windows, but since it was dark out we didn't get much of a view. The decor is pretty to look at though, so we didn't much mind.  The waiter didn't give us the happy hour menu when we sat down - we had to ask for it, which was a little annoying. He only brought one copy of it, and when I asked for more copies so we could all order (there were 6 of us) he said it was his last copy (there were no more than 10 people in the restaurant at the time).  In any case, the food was great. We ordered everything!: the Kobe Sliders (yummm!), duck rolls, edamame, oyster shooters, mussels, garlic noodles, steak fries... it was all good. The only thing I didn't like was the calamari. The thai caipirinha was also delicious - and strong! especially for a happy hour drink!  The waiter was nice enough to tell us when it was last call for happy hour. It wasn't cheap, but we got out of there for about $25 each including food, drinks and tip - pretty good in my book.  I would definitely go back here for the food!  UPDATE: Came to try the full menu and had a hard time choosing just one entree! Everything not only looked good but nearly everything I ate was delicious!   Glad those mussels and clams were still on the main menu, cuz that has the best flavor i've ever had in my life. I ordered the lobster stuffed chicken with shrimp, corn and arugula - also delicious! Blue cheese and macadamia nut crusted filet was cooked to perfection. The Chawan Mushi was a bit weird and too smoky for me, but it was unique, I'll give 'em that.  Best part was the chef came out several times to talk to us and see how we were enjoting our food. It was a great experience.

RsCUSyd-J0EPigTm_kuNaA.review_text: So, we came here with the intention of getting their mac n cheese.  I know...sad right?  Well, they changed their menu and our plan was foiled!  Their calamari is good.  You have to get their strawberry salmon spring roll!  It is really good!  Unique as well.  For lunch, I had the snapper with the lettuce wraps.  Though it was a lot of work, and messy, it was worth it.  Put some fish in the lettuce, throw some veggies from the hot plate on there, vermicelli and fish sauce.  Wrap and enjoy.  For dessert, we had the torte, which was average.  Also, the lychee ice thing with ginger...that's dessert???

287YDYKELEL71qbCSU-z-Q.review_text: Really good Asian fusion. I have tried the Kobe beef sliders, fried calamari ( def recommend), and the kahlua pork lettuce wraps and salad are super delicious. Had a drink recommended by the waiter which was also really good. Great view and vibe. Bar is crowded and parking's not too bad.

PMbivTX8hrJ5E3kqhaDtcw.review_text: i went to have dinner with my family last Friday night and was instantly greeted by the hostess upon walking in the door. I was slightly early, so I went to the bar to grab a drink and wait for the rest of my party.   I lucked out, as it was still happy hour, which runs from 4 to 7pm and has amazing appetizer selection. I could have had a great meal for cheap, but that will have to wait for another day. The bartender was sweet and very knowledgeable; she made a mean Manhattan and had a great list of cocktails to offer.   Once my family arrived we got an amazing booth by the window with a floor to ceiling view of the bay. Our server was quite attentive and recommended a delicious bottle of Rutini Malbec ( i need to find this bottle elsewhere) to go with our entrees... it was a great recommendation. We also sampled many of the cocktails from the list... we couldn't stop passing them around. Actually, come to think of it, I don't think I got mine back after the first sip.   As for the food: Ahi tempura rolls, onion soup, hamachi, pork lettuce cups, and duck rolls were only the beginning and it was a great start. The entrees were just as memorable, from the cowboy steak and whole fried fish, to the succulent duck entree; it's no wonder we didn't have anything left to take home.   Dessert can be summed up in 7 words: Banana bread pudding with macapuno (Mitchell's) ice cream. I love a place that can support local ice cream shops and makes such an amazing dessert.   Butterfly: I'll be back for round 2 very soon :0)

NSPc5WAzKjQr2D3SiFAeXg.review_text: Note: This is a review strictly for Happy Hour!  A five star happy hour!    And those stars are solid, strong, sure.    I am a huge fan of happy hours, it's one of the great perks and reasons why I love being in my mid-20s - working, finally having a disposable income for things like happy hour, having the freedom and time and luxury to enjoy these things.    I especially love happy hour places with great food, and I'm happy to say that Butterfly is now on my list of solid happy hour spots with good food and good drinks.  I came here today, around 4:30pm, with Betty W., after a stroll down the Embarcadero.  It was a great decision to stop in here.  More deets on why I'm lovin' it so hard:  + Duck confit rolls ($7) were totally delicious.  A bit pricey considering they only give you four small rolls, but they were hella tasty, my taste buds were majorly freaking out!   + The salmon crostini ($5) was pretty good too, cooling salmon on slightly salty piece of chip, and the wasabi whip cream was very light.   + The kahlua pork appetizer ($5) - they give you a GENEROUS amount of kahlua pork in a substantial bowl, with enough lettuce cups.  Add a dollop of hoisin sauce on top, and I was diggin' the perfect piece of food I held in my hand. + Betty W. got a glass of chardonnay ($5), and they give you such a HEFTY POUR.  Generous!  And pretty tasty, score!  I ordered a cocktail with Hangar One pear vodka ($5), and my eyeballs popped out of their sockets in happy surprise - you know, like one of those crazy cartoon characters.  Not the strongest I've ever had, but it was VERY tasty; the pear was very prominent and a unique, but welcoming taste.  Can I get another one, please?!  In addition, there's a nice view, although today the view was really sad and dark, but I imagine on a nice summer day, it would be gorgeous, with the water and the bay and all that lovely beautiful stuff.  I made a mental note to myself to come back here on a nice spring or summer night in 2010.  The pricing was good and reasonable too, especially for a place on the Embarcadero.  Most appetizers were $5, some were $7, and they have $1 oyster shooters and edamamme.  Cocktails and wine are $5, and they have a good beer selection (including Hefeweizen FTW!) for $3.    Our three appetizers and two drinks came out to $29 after tax - not bad at all!  In addition, our server was personable, friendly, and she even gave us a lychee from her stash after we were eyeing it and asked for one!  Food and drinks came quickly too, very efficient.  So, seriously, what's not to like?  Delicious and unique drinks, delectable and substantial appetizers that leave you respectably filled but not stuffy full, reasonable prices, and breath-taking views.     Oh yeah, add some girl talk and conversations about life-love-food-hopes-dreams-fears-and-more.  A great setting and backdrop for a good, tasty, thoughtful time with a friend.  This growing up thing ain't half bad, isn't it?  I like it more and more each day.  Cheers to Butterfly, I'll be back for sure.

K9U2qxPFi5llft8KuZIPjg.review_text: Service was really good - I was there with my 6 male co-workers who were enamored of our server's, um, decolletage and, um, friendliness.  My drinks were fine, the wine was fine, my food (seared ahi that sat on top of an onion ring that was filled with stir fried vegetables) was okay...  The stir fried veggies tasted exactly like the stir fry I make at home...and they made the onion ring soggy.   The fish was good and fresh, but didn't really go with the stir fry. The decor was a little Ikea and hollow - very echo-y.  The view was spectacular and the desserts were amazing - lots of bananas.   Not entirely sure I'd go back.  I mean, next time the team goes out for dinner, I think I'll vote for Boulevard again.

E3oy1R0su7jnehTCPx8JfQ.review_text: The food was even better this time.  Hint, the appetizers are LARGE!  We were not terribly hungry, decided to just order a few appetizers, and we barely finished them.  YUMMMM.  Excellent food, view and service, how can you go wrong?

rXg9ifwzaTZQfmL5zm5PHg.review_text: While the service was good, the filet mignon was flavorless and tasted as though it had been frozen. To their credit, management was apologetic but I would not eat here again.

f92md2NWsZTEUjI7Fr3tHw.review_text: Butterfly offers flavorful Asian fusion dishes, a relaxing ambiance and nice view right on the water. We ordered a few dishes to share:  appetizers (ahi nom nom wrap and  duck confit rolls), soup and salad (spicy seafood "milestrone" soup, smoked salmon salad roll), vegan garlic noodles and the main course dumplings and (shaking beef) steak. Everything was very fresh and flavorful, although the portion was on the small side. If you are used to eating big portion dish, you probably would have to spend a lot to feel full. It's a fancier restaurant located on Pier 33, so come here when you are not too hungry or for a special occasion as they have nice ambiance and good service.  Now on to dessert; if you are here for a special occasion dinner, do not skip dessert. We tried four dishes: warm banana ice cream pudding, classic cream brulee, warm chocolate lava cake with ice cream and lychee shaved ice. Everyone was woo-and-ahh'ing when we took the first bite at each dish;  within a few minutes everything was gone!  The warm banana ice cream pudding and lychee shaved ice was so good I wanted to order a 2nd!   The service staff was very nice and helpful too. We walked in with a party of 5 without reservation and they lead us to a nice and comfy round table right away even though it was a fairly busy night. We did have to wait a little to get our appetizers, but once we complained to our waiter, the manager came out to apologize and went out of his way to help make us happy. His recommendation on the dessert dishes were great; we were all very happy with the quality and flavor of the dishes.   My only complaint is that their menu seems to be very limited, so you don't have too many choices. If they can increase the selection on the menu with the same good execution, I could see myself come back with more friends.

E0jSWDIKgSLzInfPRvT4uQ.review_text: Scrambling to find a table last minute in the city for a party of 9 for weekend brunch is like trying to pull teeth.  So in my moment of panic, I resorted to the always loyal companion to Yelp, OpenTable.  Recommended as a "good for groups" restaurant, I was a tad apprehensive about booking it since there were so many mixed reviews.  (Well that and my party - my family - are a bunch of picky and sometimes overly critical eaters.)  But I live by the motto that "everything deserves a chance to prove me wrong" so I book it.  This had the potential for an interesting lunch.    So I arrive at the restaurant on time, and as is customary - I am the first one there.  They were glad to seat me at the table.  Surprisingly, for a restaurant right next to Pier 39, they didn't amass the crowds that are characteristic of tourist spots like the Chessecake Factory in Union Square does.  I love the space and I'm a bit of a claustrophobe so the tall ceilings and floor to ceiling windows overlooking the Bay were soothing.  The crowd was a nice mix of locals and tourists and (thankfully) a far cry from the boisterous brunch scenes that pervade this city.      15 minutes later, my family arrives.  Birthday balloons in tow.  By then, the kind waiter, Raymond had already brought us 2 bottles of waters and our pre-eats edamame.  The hostess was kind enough to alert our waiter that this was a birthday event so we arranged for a special dessert for the birthday celebrant.  The service was excellent - it was attentive without being intrusive.  Our napkins were always folded after we left for the bathroom and when I faux-pas-ed and my fork went flying mid-meal, just as I was about to pick it up off the floor, a waiter rushed right over and replaced it.  And now for the juicy part - the recap on the food.  We tried almost everything on the brunch menu - poached eggs, oysters, kalua pork, club sandwich, sashimi salad, soup duo, kobe beef burger, grilled snapper.  For dessert, we had their fried bananas lumpia (yummy goodness) and chocolate torte (a little too sweet for my tastes).  I would recommend sticking to their Asian fusion items over their American fare as these are the real stand-outs.  I sampled a little bit of everyone's plates and the Kalua pork, sashimi salad, and grilled snapper knocked my socks off! The complexity of the flavors was intense!  Hats off to the chef.  As for my family, they were (to my relief) impressed!  Crisis averted.

oVr1GZESUOHHHpfWCQ_Xkg.review_text: I came here for a dine-about-town weekend brunch and was utterly disappointed in the restaurant.   Let's talk about the good first!  1) The dessert was fantastic! There were two choices: Molten Lava Cake with Coffee Ice Cream, and Creme Brulee. I was impressed with both of them, but this may be because I had to wait 30 minutes after finishing my mediocre main-dish to experience them (more on waiting later).   2) Some appetizers were interesting. I had the fried calamari which was topped with what looked like Cilantro/Coriander sprouts. Very unique and different!  Okay, now that the good is over with, let's get to what didn't go so well...  1) "Brunch" took 2.5 hours to finish. Most of this time was spent waiting for things to come. After our appetizers, we waited at least 30 minutes before our main dishes (they screwed up the order on these, by the way) came out. And the same wait after our main dishes for our desserts. Oh by the way, they delivered some of the appetizers to us within minutes of our ordering. In fact, they had mistakenly delivered them to us -- they were actually intended for another table. My table of six paid a required 18% gratiuity for this haltingly slow service.   2) The food was mediocre. Besides desserts and the appetizer I had, everything was overall mediocre. I had the torta topped with egg and this strange strongly-"blueish"-cheese that was melted. This course was greasy and tasted very strange due to the cheese. I also tried the duck confit egg roll appetizer -- ugh. Who came up with the sauce for that one? The wasabi in the sauce was enough to burn a hole through my stuffed up nose. And the duck itself was bland and tasteless. I would have been happier eating normal egg rolls.   Maybe it was dine about town, or maybe this restaurant is overhyped. In any case, I'm not going back anytime soon.

5xFkiPEarQUZMbUcJYz8Rg.review_text: If you read my reviews you'll notice I give really great family style restaurants a fairly easy 5 stars; but the trendy, pricey places need to work for that 5th star. For obvious reasons ($$$). I couldn't decide: 4 or 5 stars?  But there was something on my last visit that put Butterfly over the 4 star edge... sugar water. This was maybe my seventh visit to Butterfly since I started working in the wharf neighborhood about 2 years ago. I first came here as part of the "Dine About Town" event (check it out - sfdineabouttown.com) I had an excellent meal and have since returned for celebratory lunches for coworkers or meeting family on the wharf while at work. Every time the food has been consistently delicious, the service attentive and the view is lovely, too (right on the water). We came to celebrate my coworker's move to Korea--it was his last day in our office. The waiter brought the two plates of edamame that come in place of the restaurant standard bread basket. These edamame are very yummy - drizzled with a sesame based, rice vinegar dressing and sesame seeds and salt--the best edamame in town. We also ordered their calamari which are crispy, light and nicely spiced with a piquant dipping sauce. We fought (politely) over the last piece. I recommended the Tumeric Grilled Snapper and two of the group gave this a try. It's the best dish on the menu and always pleases--sizzling snapper and onions and fennel served up in a small cast iron pan with Vietnamese style accoutrements: lettuce for rolling up the tasty fish, bean sprouts, mint and rice noodles and a dipping sauce to finish it off just right. I decided to stray from that favorite of mine and tried the Sashimi Trio Salad -- this was also well prepared and served with a sticky black Thai rice that I've never had before. It wasn't as satisfying as the snapper, but a good light meal. My friend next to me had the coconut curry chicken which would've been my second choice and it looked very interesting and tasty. I might try it next time... I had ordered a pot of hot tea - a marvelously fragrant earl grey -- and was looking around the table for the cream. I saw that my friend had a little white pitcher next to his plate so I asked "is that cream?"--he said  "No, it's like sugar dissolved in water" -- I then saw he was having an ice tea. That did it. This place is now definitely five stars. I like ice tea...do you like ice tea? If you do, you'll know what an effort it is to try and get sugar to dissolve in an icy liquid. Fifth Star: Attention to detail. One criticism--what is with the billing process? We are always coming here from work for lunch, so the wait for the check OR the wait for the return of the credit card is abysmally long and frustrating. Every time. I often get up and retrieve it to expedite our departure. But not enough of a complaint to detract from the excellent food.

5YUfy39pMeDI_ZNuAj2Iig.review_text: Excellent service. Wait staff very attentive. Napkin was refolded when a member left the table, and water glasses refilled promptly. Enjoyed the beautiful presentation and generous portions. Our party of 4 enjoyed all our Asian fusion dishes and the creative Asian cocktails.  Our favorite was the Kaluha lettuce cups. They had live music here during the holidays and this was a very nice touch to our evening out in the city.

6_VkzelWeSHzjTVDlGl-Ug.review_text: FOOD: 1.) smoked salmon strawberry salad spring roll 2.) cod entree - so soft  SERVICE: Good  ATMOSPHERE: Nice, trendy, modern, open .. big, some big windows overlooking towards the Bay

6bn9sde-6wjT23WcakGcbA.review_text: Butterfly defies the stereotype that a restaurant with a great location, design and interior space, with a terrific view and friendly, good looking staff, could not have food or drink of any interest. I have now been there several times with my family and there hasn't been a miss yet. Our favorites include the Kailua pig in lettuce cups, duck confit spring rolls, Kalbi slyle hangar steak, and the cowboy steak; salads are well done too, fresh and crisp and light. Room is very comfortable, and seems to work well for a mixed crowd of business types, dates, and families, even tourists!

WjsofKsjiRtZjFnlWlAPVA.review_text: I love Butterfly.  I've been here for lunch, dinner, and parties.  I love the space, the view, the decor..............the food is delicious.  I've not once been disappointed.  The service is good, prompt, and the wait staff is friendly.  I love that Butterfly now does take out for lunch.  I always order something different when I eat there and it's all so very yummy.  I thought they had a very decent wine list as well.  There is plenty of street parking and two lots very close by.

IEFI5N8O-uBDfsCgD7bf7g.review_text: Recently went there and the place was OK. I won't go into it but something has changed there.

Tz1FRUGfq7xBf4-ZGlvLZg.review_text: the food here was ehhhh, not all that great like i thought it would be from all the hype. you either do asian fusion real well or it usually ends up tasting like you tried too hard.  the only thing i like about this restaurant was the actual restaurant itself. large windows that over look the water and the decorations were pretty.

eY4X7aZNLzvWDuho7mrI0Q.review_text: Worst place ever!  Said entrance for New Year's was at 9:30.  It's 10:30 and just getting in now.  I would give it 0 stars if I could.

Cq9lqRaMAJzzEazQrLbNrg.review_text: The meal started off with a hostess who was very accommodating with table selection, even though we arrived early for our reservation. The wait staff was attentive and helpful. The food was great, from the well crafted smoked salmon and strawberry salad rolls and generous garlic noodle appetizers to the inventive seared king salmon (in minestrone) and tasty sesame crusted snapper (ran out of tuna). The cocktails were unique and the iron skillet chocolate cookie with mint chocolate chip ice cream was a fun way to end the evening. An all around good meal.

g5JvNSSkz6q04uvDcqSU_g.review_text: This is a cool little place.  Before heading out to catch a later boat ride at the pier, we decided to grab something to eat.  I really love the selection of restaurants the embarcadero offers and after stopping and reading each menu along the embarcadero the restaurants had presented, this place as well as there menu, happened to strick the most interest.  Ambiance and decor of this restaurant is very modern, ultra, chic- with a very cool dark earth tone color scheme throughout offering some extremely interesting high tech metal chandler's and art décor throughout the rest of the restaurant- the layout is spacious, the bar is gorgeous and the views are nice. The only thing that through off the decor of the overall restaurant was the bamboo wall divider separating the kitchen and the rest of the restaurant, just looked slightly sloppy (just me) but overall very cool.  We got a nice seat by the window unfortunately, with our backs facing the window but still a nice table with views of the restaurant.  They have an interesting menu with a nice selection of appealing dishes to choose from- some basics such as burgers and sandwiches, as well as some specialty dishes. The also have an nice selection of temtacious cocktails to choose from so while waiting for our food, I decided to indulge in the white sake sangria which is 9 gekkeikan sake, skyy berry vodka, acai juice- this drink arrived delicious looking filled with a mixture of berries and tasted absolutely fan tab!  I was in carnivore protein mode so, I ordered the House Ground American Kobe Beef Burger (with out the bun for me and which usually comes with fries) however, I opted for a salad with a side dressing of some sort of special ginger dressing. My babe ordered Grilled Chicken Salad Club 12-Avocado, Swiss cheese, Bacon, Steak Fries.  You are given a bowl of incredibly tasty Seasoned Edamame  included with lunch which was a perfect light option before our meal.  Our meals arrived shortly after finishing our edamame. My burger arrived nice juicy and appealing (smaller in size) though, tasted incredible and the quality of the meat was definitly a notice. The salad on the side was slightly scarse and could have used some more ruffage though, the dressing it was accompanied with was absolutely creamy and delcisous.  The one thing I did not care for was the little bowl filled with salt for use. Sorry, who knows if people dip there fingers in it or what not and guess I just prefer the even spread from a regular salt and pepper shaker.  Overall, it's an incredibly cool place to dine in and really would look forward to coming back again perhaps in the evening.

tLj-1t4y56oijKrDn-cVOw.review_text: Bacon is what I like to call the "gate way drug" to meat eating.  I went to Butterfly's to-go lunch counter for the Clam Chowder and not only did it have shrimp but BACON... oh good lord...I'm a fish/veggie eater...so I was kinda bummin' about the bacon at first. I was so hungry...so I ate it anyway (shhhh...don't tell)... and I have to say... it was delish! Okay okay...maybe the fatty bacon-y goodness was what did it. But I'd like to think that it was sourdough bread they put at the bottom of my to-go bowl.  This place likes to kick things up a notch... Don't just give me a piece of bread with my soup...put the bread UNDER the soup...to soak up the buttery creamy goodness... then get that bacon in there and - WHAM! Heart-Pattering-Happiness.  I find that this is a nice place to go for a to-go meal...just as much as all the other places near by... although I will make sure to be sure they don't have meat in my food - they weren't too slammed to accommodate my busy schedule during my short lunch break. Plus - if you've got the time...you can go and sit on the dock... sittin' on the dock of the bay - with your bacon-y soup.  Yum.

Gf8dXl8t257aoCXXJ4v_Og.review_text: Been here for dinner, a private party, and happy hour. Excellent x 3!

hhabD3IvEUIJkh7kFa2gbg.review_text: Hadn't heard of this place until a friend suggested it, but so glad we tried it!  Easy to get to via BART and the Muni F streetcar.  We had an early reservation (5:30) but service was still kinda slow at first. But once our order went in, stuff kept comin'.  They started us off with yummy edamame tossed with sesame seeds and that cool red hawaiian salt. We ordered appetizers that turned out to be way too much food. The Kalua Pork in Butter Lettuce cups was tasty tasty tasty--that is a five star appetizer. Ahi Tuna Tempura roll with sticky thai black rice was very creative. Mussels in coconut curry with toasted french bread for dipping. Fried calamari was good (I would have liked more tentacles tho').   Dessert was Banana Bread Pudding with Mitchell's Macapuno Ice cream and macadamia brittle. SO GOOD.  The bread pudding had nice crunchy topping to it, the ice cream was perfect cold creamy contrast, but you could still taste the macapuno (young preserved coconut strings, in case you don't know what that is). and the brittle was a delightful crunch on the side.  Got seated at the window, and it was a picture-perfect afternoon. Boats going by, sea lion frolicking in the water. Nice!  I am not normally a fan of nouveau-asian-looks-pretty-on-the-plate fare (I'm a hole-in-the-wall gal) but this was artfully presented AND it tasted good! hooray!  This would be a great place for a gal's night out, drinks with friends, or a date.

DFDWPcs-bm1a7UW3XavOaA.review_text: Very good though limited menu Great ambience and fabulous drinks Try the fried whole fish

DmAHfq2q9MfOvRRkJIYe9w.review_text: This is a wonderful place to go and enjoy a nice lunch or dinner.  I had the Chicken Salad Club and the Garlic Noodles.  WOW, it was fantastic, the service was excellent.  Probably the best food, i'm had in a long time.   The Owner and waiters were so nice.  Love this place....

_zW6Q6LEu1vjnSKlvcvoOQ.review_text: Loved the food and the friendly - Chef/Owner. The Kewi/Cucumber signature drink went down easy and the environment was warm and cozy with just the right amount of flash. The sea urchin lights, the water front location and great parking for the city on a week night made everything better. The whole fish, garlic noodles and signature Kula pork wraps not necessarily in that order were more than a couple could handle.... All said it was a great night of foodie dining in the City. A definite recommend for date night or a nice moment out for two or more.

-TIvi4-ch_SHe-5NhEesRg.review_text: I am a fan!! I took my girlfriend here for our anniversary and it was great. We were the only people in the restaurant mid week so we didnt have to wait long for a table, and we got some premium seating along one of the window couch set ups. Unfortunately the view went to waste since it was dark at night and the couches face inward due to the place turning into a lounge at night. hehe.   Anyhoo getting back to the food. We first started off with some delicious starters such as the Fire Fried Calamari, Duck Conift Spring Rolls and The Kalua Pig Butter Lettuce Cups!!! OMG the lettuce cups were so delicious!! The duck spring rolls were pretty tasty, our duck wasn't gamey like some others have posted. The Calamari was the big let down of the night, but the other 2 appetizers made up for it.   For our main entree we split the Grilled Hanger Steak! I had no idea that it was a sizzlin steak and like fajitas it came on a big sizzlin skillet! the only big draw back is that the smoke made me smell like meat all night! hahaha so if you are planning on going out afterwards you may want to come prepared. hahaha. (extra shirt) ;) The fingerling potatoes were awesome, they were crispy on the outside but the inside was so soft. Everything about the meal was delicious from beginning to end.   We actually ordered too much food, and we took home left overs. Thank you Butterfly you truly made our evening delightful.

vASaF47nWvCHEEDA8nfCVw.review_text: This restaurant is best enjoyed in a small group... I'm talking 4 - 6 people.  We came here the other day with a large group and, it being a Saturday night, the restaurant was pretty full.    We were probably the largest group that night, so at least two servers for our table would have been expected.  The service was real slow at the beginning, the appetizer came about an hour after we were seated, and a few of us were waiting for the drinks for almost an hour before the server came and told us that they ran out.  Despite that, soon as the appetizers came out (deep fried calamari, duck spring rolls, smoked salmon carpaccio, all of which are very tasty), the entrees follow soon after.  The service got better throughout the night, and the desserts were delicious.    The location and interior decoration is great, with food and drinks (lychee martini!!!!) to match.    I would come back here again.  This time, with a smaller group.

43lYaPQ6dGuIt1Iwd-eYZg.review_text: We decided on this place for a celebration lunch for my team of ten. We order appetizers and lunch. I can say the calamari was quite good, although the potions for the price were very disappointing.   The trio salad (fish) was fair, but the sauce over powered the fish and there was no mention of wasabi in the menu description.   Mainly, the service was terrible. The wait staff was lazy, rude, and mostly ignored us. If the tip wasn't included in the bill - we would not have tipped at all. As it was, we did not leave over the included amount. It is because of the staff and the two hour long wait for our entrees that we will NEVER eat here again.   We order mostly burgers and the fish salad, and the place was empty by the time we received our food. For a four hundred dollar meal, we could of eaten somewhere better. I do not recommend this restaurant to anyone.

ggt3_ieuoR66GA-Ewf6EDQ.review_text: 1st time visit:  Appetizer: kalua pork wraps, calamari, and garlic noodles. All tasted so amazing. Great portion size-shared by 3.  Main course- I had the special for the night- lobster pot pie- very flaky and lots of lobster chunks!  Dessert- the most amazing banana bread pudding with coconut ice cream ever! It was so good I came back a second night just for the dessert!  Overall the service was great and I have nothing bad to say at all.

SJ7X28HZXtyvNIJavcXxFQ.review_text: Good food near Pier 39?  From now on, this is going to be my answer:  Butterfly at pier 33 (about 3 blocks East of Pier 39)  Saw a review of it on Check Please (television show), and thought we'd give it a go.  It's been around for about 10 years, but I haven't been until yesterday.  And it's a winner in my book.  Not touristy schlock, but really good food at very reasonable prices.  It's Asian Fusion.  Which some say is over done, but it makes so much sense here in SF with our influences and ingredients.  After a couple of cocktails.  We had the sashimi and poke starter and a calamari appetizer, which were fantastic.  He uses the belly (toro) portion of the tuna for the poke which melts in your mouth, and he uses the loin of the hamachi which was like butter.  So you pay a little more than your average raw fish, but it was goooood.  The Calamari comes with sort of a ponzu sauce and remoulade, and it was the most tender calamari I've had.  The chef came out and made fun of himself a little, saying that reviewers often say the mark of a bad restaurant is if there's calamari on the menu, so he said he put it on the menu just 'cuz.  It was good.   Our main dish, which we shared, was a seared duck breast and a duck confit.  It has some really nice soy and citrus flavors.  Perfectly tender, with crispy skin outside.  Really amazing.  For dessert, banana bread pudding.  Really good and custardy, rich and sweet, but not overly so.  Really hit the spot.  The portions are not huge, and what we ordered didn't have a lot of carbs to fill you up, so we were satisfied without being stuffed.  Our check with 3 drinks, came out to under $80.  Which for the quality of the food and location was excellent.  It's a place you can afford to come to on a weeknight and not feel like you're indulging too much.  The service was fantastic.  I noted that it was our anniversary when I booked through Open Table, and they gave us a fantastic table with the best view.  They also threw in our dessert for free wishing us a happy night.  The Chef, Robert Lam, came out and chatted with us several times, which I really liked.  He's really down to earth.  Turns out he graduated from the school I teach at and he said he's willing to come back and maybe do some stuff with our students.    The design is modern, and clean.  You can stroll in off of the pier in jeans and feel at home, or be a little dressed up and not be out of place.  It's lively without being raucous.  A really nice spot that locals and visitors should check out.  Parking is not fantastic.  Taking the F line would be your best bet.  But especially if you're already down there and hungry, I'd go to Butterfly before any other place within a mile of the Pier.  We'll be back to try many of the other dishes.

0BypTx7HWe0beJHHXMr9Bw.review_text: the banana bread pudding here is worth many visits to come. warm, buttery, gooey, sticky sweet, great banana flavor, not to much or too little, the perfect end to a beautiful meal.  i loved the stellar service during our work function. our party of 20 was well taken care of, everything was amazing, drinks were filled, food was delicious, service was prompt until the check came. once the check was dropped off, we were ignored for a good 20 minutes.

GmYe7X1js7ArVjFWP6-sQA.review_text: Went here for brunch with four friends today (Sunday). The menu was very short and they were out of the one vegetarian item they were offering (maui onion soup). I ordered a chicken salad club sandwich ($12), it was okay, but I had to scrape off the chicken salad because it had way too much mayonnaise. There were only two small slices of avocado :( Also, I could tell that the steak fries had been fried in the same oil with fish because there was a slightly fishy taste to the oil (my friends who love seafood did not notice this, but since I hate seafood it was annoying for me). The server was very competent but pretty snobby. He added a 18% gratuity to our checks even though this is only supposed to be done for parties of 6 or more.
